articles.headline: Drug Maker’s Donations to Co-Pay Charity Face Scrutiny
articles.snippet: An inquiry into Questcor Pharmaceuticals’ marketing practices has cast a spotlight on an open secret: The bulk of the contributions that help patients pay for medicines come from the drug firms themselves.
articles.abstract: An inquiry into Questcor Pharmaceuticals’ marketing practices has cast a spotlight on an open secret: The bulk of the contributions that help patients pay for medicines come from the drug firms themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: As drug prices have soared in recent years and insurers have increased co-payments, a new type of charity has blossomed to fill a vital niche — helping patients pay the steep out-of-pocket costs for their medicines.

articles.headline: Obama Is Urged to Sharply Curb N.S.A. Data Mining
articles.snippet: A panel of advisers urged President Obama to change the way the National Security Agency collects the telephone data of Americans, spies on foreign leaders and prepares for cyberattacks abroad.
articles.abstract: A panel of advisers urged President Obama to change the way the National Security Agency collects the telephone data of Americans, spies on foreign leaders and prepares for cyberattacks abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A panel of outside advisers urged President Obama on Wednesday to impose major oversight and some restrictions on the National Security Agency, arguing that in the past dozen years its powers had been enhanced at the expense of personal privacy.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Fed to Start Unwinding Its Stimulus Next Month
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve said that it would gradually end its bond-buying program during 2014 but strengthened plans to hold short-term interest rates near zero.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve said that it would gradually end its bond-buying program during 2014 but strengthened plans to hold short-term interest rates near zero.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that it would gradually end its bond-buying program during 2014, a modest first step toward unwinding the central bank’s broader stimulus campaign as its officials gain confidence that the economy is growing steadily.

articles.headline: Former SAC Trader Is Convicted of Insider Trading
articles.snippet: Michael S. Steinberg is the highest-ranking employee at SAC Capital Advisors to become ensnared in a sweeping insider trading investigation.
articles.abstract: Michael S. Steinberg is the highest-ranking employee at SAC Capital Advisors to become ensnared in a sweeping insider trading investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:50 p.m. | Prosecutors lacked the incriminating wiretaps that underpinned past insider trading cases. The emails pointed to no smoking gun. And the government’s star witness, a felon who testified to avoid prison time, fumbled his way through five days of cross-examination.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess, Matthew Goldstein and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Wireless Speakers Let Music Roam Free
articles.snippet: Newer wireless models deliver sound that can satisfy a demanding listener, from relatively small packages.
articles.abstract: Newer wireless models deliver sound that can satisfy a demanding listener, from relatively small packages.
articles.lead_paragraph: You may have noticed the spate of new wireless audio speakers on the market, many of them marketed to be sold in multiples and placed throughout the house. For the speaker companies, it isn’t all about function and audio science: their priority is to sell you five or six speakers at a time. Your priority should be to figure out what you want from music.

articles.headline: Uninsured Skeptical of Health Care Law in Poll
articles.snippet: Americans who lack medical coverage disapprove of the new health law at roughly the same rate as the insured, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.abstract: Americans who lack medical coverage disapprove of the new health law at roughly the same rate as the insured, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Americans who lack medical coverage disapprove of President Obama’s health care law at roughly the same rate as the insured, even though most say they struggle to pay for basic care, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Abby Goodnough and Allison Kopicki

articles.headline: First on the List, a Blank
articles.snippet: Analysts and retailers, already expecting sluggish holiday sales, say that a truly dominant fashion trend has yet to emerge this year.
articles.abstract: Analysts and retailers, already expecting sluggish holiday sales, say that a truly dominant fashion trend has yet to emerge this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: All of a sudden, Ugg boots were everywhere. Knee-high Hunter rain boots also seemed to sprout from the ground directly onto millions of American feet. And last year, denim in the colors of Skittles candies, like green and red, were inescapable.

articles.headline: Brazil Snubs Boeing in Fighter Jet Deal
articles.snippet: The announcement that Brazil picked the aircraft maker Saab for a $4.5 billion contract to build 36 fighter jets comes at a time of heightened tension with the United States over spying.
articles.abstract: The announcement that Brazil picked the aircraft maker Saab for a $4.5 billion contract to build 36 fighter jets comes at a time of heightened tension with the United States over spying.
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — In a disappointment for Boeing, Brazilian defense officials said on Wednesday that they had picked the aircraft maker Saab for a $4.5 billion contract to build 36 fighter jets over the next 10 years.
articles.byline: By Dan Horch and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: Health Insurers Extend Deadline for First Premiums
articles.snippet: Nearly all the major insurers have agreed to cover their customers retroactively if they go to the emergency room or doctor’s office after Jan. 1, but send in their payment by Jan. 10.
articles.abstract: Nearly all the major insurers have agreed to cover their customers retroactively if they go to the emergency room or doctor’s office after Jan. 1, but send in their payment by Jan. 10.
articles.lead_paragraph: Insurance companies, worried about potential chaos next month as people begin seeking coverage under the federal health care law without completing the necessary paperwork, have agreed to give consumers an extra 10 days to pay their first-month premiums, according to a statement from the companies’ trade group on Wednesday.

articles.headline: After Bangladesh Factory Collapse, Bleak Struggle for Survivors
articles.snippet: Eight months after more than 1,100 Bangladeshi workers died and many were injured in the Rana Plaza disaster, survivors and families are left with no guarantees of help or compensation.
articles.abstract: Eight months after more than 1,100 Bangladeshi workers died and many were injured in the Rana Plaza disaster, survivors and families are left with no guarantees of help or compensation.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAVAR, Bangladesh — Inside the single room he shares with his wife and young child, Hasan Mahmud Forkan does not sleep easily. Some nights he hears the screams of the garment workers he tried to rescue from the wreckage of the Rana Plaza factory building. Or he dreams the bed itself is collapsing, sucking him down into a bottomless void.

articles.headline: Target Struck in the Cat-and-Mouse Game of Credit Theft
articles.snippet: The theft is the latest blow struck in a technological cat-and-mouse game between retailers and criminals, who experts say can attack along a wide variety of avenues.
articles.abstract: The theft is the latest blow struck in a technological cat-and-mouse game between retailers and criminals, who experts say can attack along a wide variety of avenues.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Target may have been an easy bull’s-eye for criminal hackers intent on stealing credit card information, but the theft of records for 40 million store customers was hardly the worst security breach among big retailers in recent years. And the incident revealed on Thursday is unlikely to be the last.

articles.headline: Putin, Secure in Power, Says He May Free Jailed Rival
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin said that Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon, could soon be freed from prison, a reversal many saw as an attempt to quiet critics before the Winter Olympics.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin said that Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon, could soon be freed from prison, a reversal many saw as an attempt to quiet critics before the Winter Olympics.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin said on Thursday that Russia could soon free its most famous prisoner, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former chief executive of Yukos Oil, whose arrest and jailing 10 years ago signaled an authoritarian turn in the nation’s modern history.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and David M. Herszenhorn
